pullRequest.body:
We define [polynomial sequences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_sequence) -- that is, sequences of polynomials where the `i`th polynomial has degree `i`.

We do not yet refactor any existing polynomial sequences to go via this proof (e.g. for the usual monomial basis which has its own proof already in Mathlib).
    
Co-authored-by: Aaron Hill <aa1ronham@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Julian Berman <Julian@GrayVines.com>
Co-authored-by: Matej Penciak <matej.penciak@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Austin Letson <waustinletson@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [4626ccb716](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20846/commits/4626ccb71609ddd0f37a3e23a9dd870a7b69ae27)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Sequence` (new file)|1023|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Sequence`
`+ basis`
`+ basis_degree_injective`
`+ basis_degree_lt`
`+ basis_eq_self`
`+ basis_natDegree_injective`
`+ basis_natDegree_lt`
`+ bass_degree_inj`
`+ bass_natDegree_inj`
`+ coeFun`
`+ degree_eq`
`+ degree_inj`
`+ degree_injective`
`+ degree_lt`
`+ degree_smul_of_isRightRegular_leadingCoeff`
`+ linearIndependent`
`+ natDegree_eq`
`+ natDegree_inj`
`+ natDegree_injective`
`+ natDegree_lt`
`+ ne_zero`
`+ span`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@Ruben-VandeVelde I couldn't figure out how to generalize this to semirings honestly :/. Putting it back in review after some other light reworking, presuming that perhaps in a follow-up someone may give me a tip. Let me know if you don't think that's reasonable of course.

I *believe* I've covered all the suggestions @EtienneC30, thanks for all the tips! And asked on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Linear.20independence.20of.20polynomial.20sequences.20over.20semirings/near/501168170) about the last remaining generalization (which I've added a TODO for).
Results about injectivity and lt on degree and natDegree can likely be stated as StrictMono. There is a StrictMono.injective.
Thanks!
I left a few remarks about conventions and possible shortenings.
This PR is nice! Could you add some API for the basis please? At least `S.basis hCoeff i = S i`.

I added the specific one you suggested -- I couldn't immediately think of others nor find another basis whose API I could cargo cult (or learn what typically is provided).

If you have any other suggestions please feel free to teach me!

(Or otherwise at some point we may try to formalize some change-of-basis theorems about changing between polynomial sequence bases and then maybe it'll be obvious what API we need ourselves?)

Thanks! I guess you can also add a lemma giving the degree: `(S.basis hCoeff i).degree = i`, and equivalents for `natDegree_eq` and `degree_ne_degree`. As your objects have certain properties and are then wrapped in the basis I figure it is simpler to transfer these properties to the element of the basis directly. Of course it's hard to anticipate what will be needed. As you say, the best way to find out is to use it!

When referring to a definition like `IsRightRegular`, we usually don't abbreviate it in the name, and segments should go in outer-inner order
```suggestion
theorem degree_smul_of_isRightRegular_leadingCoeff {k : R} (hk: k ≠ 0)
```

```suggestion
/-- Make `S i` mean `S.elems' i`. -/
```
or rename the field
Do we want a variant of this lemma with `Function.Injective`, maybe?
Added (hopefully correctly).
This proof doesn't immediately generalize, but is this true over semirings?
I wasn't sure, and I saw lots of the linear independence API being generalized the last few weeks to Semirings. I'll look again to see if perhaps now I can find something that works.

I discussed the question with a friend today and our conclusion is that this will only be true over semirings which have injective addition, i.e. `a + b = a + c -> b = c` (this would be [AddCancelCommMonoid](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Defs.html#AddCancelCommMonoid)). Counter-example: if `a + c = b + c` but `a ≠ b`, you have `a • 1 + c • (1 + X) = b • 1 + c • (1 + X)` while `a ≠ b`. In the case of an `AddCancelCommMonoid` it will be true since the space of polynomials will also be an `AddCancelCommMonoid`. This in particular covers the case of `ℕ`. However I did not find a typeclass in `Mathlib` to talk about such semirings, so I would say that the way to go here is to write a TODO mentioning the missing typeclass (if it is missing, maybe it would be nice to open a Zulip thread to make sure).

```suggestion
    refine degree_ne_bot.mp ?_ eqzero |>.elim
```

I think this is more sensible to state as
```suggestion
    span R (Set.range S) = ⊤ := by
```

That would have been what I expected too, but this is how it's spelled in `Basis.mk`'s argument, and I assumed whatever reasoning applied there applied elsewhere (I guess because `\le` is easier to prove than `\eq` or something?) And then I saw other span API also use this kind of spelling.

Or are you aware of all that and telling me it's still better to phrase the standalone lemma this way?

I once wrote a lemma with the conclusion being `⊤ ≤ ...` and was told that `... = ⊤` was better because it allows to rewrite directly. I think the idea of `⊤ ≤ ...` is as you said that it allows to only prove one inequality, but `eq_top_iff` can help with that so I think it's better (and more paper math friendly) to write `... = ⊤`.
Aha! The rewrite thing makes sense -- though I'm left still wondering then why `Basis.mk` doesn't take a proof of `=`. But thanks, that makes enough sense for now to me!

```suggestion
  by_cases p_ne_zero : P = 0
  · simp [p_ne_zero]
```

You can reuse variables already introduced in the file here. If you write `#where` (in VSCode at least) it prints available variables, in this case the polynomial `p` is already there, and you can replace `k` with one of the scalars.
```suggestion
theorem degree_smul_of_isRightRegular_leadingCoeff (ha : a ≠ 0)
    (hp : IsRightRegular p.leadingCoeff) : (a • p).degree = p.degree := by
```
Aha, nice!

I think it's more idiomatic to use `refine` with the syntax `?_`. Do you have a particular reason to prefer `apply`?
```suggestion
  refine le_antisymm (degree_smul_le k p) <| degree_le_degree ?_
```
This file had multiple authors, so possibly it originally used `apply`, but agree, I also like refine better.

```suggestion
  /-- The `i`'th element in the sequence has degree `i`. Use `S.degree_eq` instead. -/
```
You can remove the empty docstring, same below.

I don't think those are the conventional way to do things. Looking at the [naming convention for injectivity](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html#injectivity), You should rather state
```lean
lemma degree_inj {i j : ℕ} : (S i).degree = (S j).degree ↔ i = j
```
(and potentially make it a `simp` lemma). Then if you want the version with `≠` you can use `(degree_inj S).ne`. Same remark for `natDegree`.
Aha, I'd not seen that section, thanks! I'll have a closer look.
Again according to the convention these should be named `degree_injective` and `natDegree_injective`.

There is no real policy here, but using an explicit universe variable is not necessary and might suggest something special is going on, so I would advise to just use `Type*`.
```suggestion
variable (R : Type*)
```
(I copied from `Polynomial/Basis.lean`, but it looked odd to me there too, so I indeed meant to change to `Type*`, thanks for catching!)

You can immediately take care of the trivial case using the `triviality` tactic.
```suggestion
  eq_top_iff'.mpr fun P ↦ by
  nontriviality R using Subsingleton.eq_zero P
```
Nice trick, hadn't seen that tactic before and it did bother me to have to do it via `by_cases`. thanks!
I discovered it this week myself :)

I had a slight hope this would work a few lines down for handling:

```
    by_cases tail_eq_zero : tail = 0
    · simp [head_mem_span, sub_eq_iff_eq_add.mp tail_eq_zero]
```

via

```
nontriviality tail
```

but it doesn't, and the error message is quite funny, it says "unknown identifier tail" (which seems like it must be a minor bug?)

Do you understand why not? I guess being equal to 0 is not a `Nontrivial` instance? And there's no similar fun "prove nonzero" tactic?

Can you use `induction` instead of `induction'` please? We prefer the former because it gives more structured proofs. You can keep the proof unchanged doing this:
```suggestion
  · generalize hp : P.natDegree = n
    induction n using Nat.strong_induction_on generalizing P with
    | h n ih =>
```

When you do a proof `by_cases` and the first case is easy you can drop the dot and the indentation for the other case.
```suggestion
    refine sub_mem_iff_left _ head_mem_span |>.mp ?_
```

You can directly do (the `simp` does nothing)
```suggestion
    · refine sub_mem_iff_left _ head_mem_span |>.mp <| ih tail.natDegree ?_ _ rfl
```

This is a non terminal `simp` to it should be turned into a `simp only`. But you can also use the syntax `simpa ... using ...`.
```suggestion
        simpa [leadingCoeff_smul_of_smul_regular _ <| IsSMulRegular.of_mul_eq_one leftinv, rightinv]
          using isRegular_one.right
```
It was originally a `simpa` and I was trying to simplify it further I think and forgot to change back.

No need for that much indentation in `rw`. Same is true above.
```suggestion
          rwa [n_eq_zero, eq_C_of_natDegree_eq_zero <| S.natDegree_eq 0,
            smul_C, smul_eq_mul, map_mul, ← C_mul, rightinv, smul_C, smul_eq_mul,
            mul_one, C_eq_zero, leadingCoeff_eq_zero]
```
Again you can drop the dot and the indent in the second case here.
Same remark as before about the injectivity convention. If you think these specialized versions are still useful (even though we have `Iff.ne`) it's fine to keep them as well I think.

pullRequest.title: feat(Polynomial): polynomial sequences are bases for R[X]
